text: hi everyone anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd and it is
time for a review of the new
imperial triumphant record alphaville
this is the newest full-length lp from
new york avant-garde metal
outfit imperial triumphant it has been a
few years since their album vile luxury
which served as an amazing introduction
to the band for me
a record that was extreme technical very
versatile
as well and surprisingly not even
bordering on gimmicky despite its
mind-bending fusions of
black metal death metal jazz and
alphaville here essentially sounds like
the band is upping
the ante with a clearer recording
monstrous vocals relentless riffs and
rhythms
and more curious genre fusions too like
the sudden passage of
tribal hand drums that pop into the
middle of city swine
or the barbershop quartet vocals that
open up atomic age
which keeps with the band's love of
futurism
there's also the forlorn jazzy intro to
transmission to mercury then later in
the track an unlikely horn solo
alien coral harmonies that resolve
pretty beautifully at a few points and
then
some yoko ono-esque vocal freakouts
while alphaville doesn't feature quite
as many bold and straightforward extreme
metal and jazz fusions as
vile luxury did the band is still taking
a lot of risks on this one
and doing it without sounding like a
zany metal novelty where
everything the band does has to sound
preposterous or
silly ultimately i think the key may lie
in that no matter what imperial
triumphant is
attempting on a track the final result
is
harrowing abrasive and surprising now
the nine tracks on this record span
an hour and almost every moment on this
lp
is oppressive winding disorienting
very dense but simultaneously
invigorating
too as the sound the band conjures on
this record is so
thrilling and so fiery packed with
maddening compositional ideas and
transitions and builds
like the sliding and melting dissonant
guitar lines on the greater
good pretty sure the band has captured
the soundtrack to
going insane and while the material here
is obviously very flashy and requires a
lot of technical ability to pull off
it's not cold calculated wankery that's
so robotic in execution it sounds like
ai generated noise
alphaville is evocative to say the least
with the start of the intro track rotted
futures we have this tense
dissonant swell of instrumentation that
leads to these
fragmented and off-kilter ringing sour
guitar leads and riffs
the track sounds like i'm just trapped
in a spinning
wondrous labyrinth of horrors that gets
more and more disorienting
as the band goes harder and harder and
harder
kind of reminding me of the band portal
in a way but a lot more melodic ideas
translating also the behold the future
choral vocals that are worked into this
track are frightening as [ __ ] we have
more explosive and aggressive guitars
and drums on the track excelsior
where we get these speedy jazz grind
drum passages propelling some of the
most
hideous and just garish riffs and leads
on the entire record
there's a lot of black metal influence
coming out of the harmonies and guitar
layering on this track too but it's
pushed to
such an extreme it's almost
unrecognizable plus the detuned
breakdown in the second half
is incredible as well then the somewhat
industrial
outro is so massive and crushing i mean
one of the most momentous
moments on the record too frankly i'm
not as crazy about the track city swine
the super
sparse and just acidic
and tangy guitar leads that kind of
twang
and just ring their way throughout the
first leg of this song
they're a bit too stripped back and
skeletal something seems
missing from this portion of the track
that is sort of here throughout the rest
of the record but
the second portion is a lot more densely
layered gratifying visceral
the following atomic age though is
easily one of the most exciting tracks
on the lp
there are portions of this song that
actually remind me of liturgy a little
bit
and how the band is able to so maximally
pack
so much sound and so much melody and so
much noise into a single moment
but with all of it still translating
pretty well
there is a very foreboding first leg
with the synced
up rhythms and staccato guitar riffs
that follow the barbershop
quartet portion that i mentioned earlier
sorry if it's a little hard to keep
track because there are so many
transitions and changes and in various
sections to all of these songs
but this song mostly feels like an
experiment in taking this very
off-kilter groove and slowly filling
in all of the gaps with more and more
just
hideous sounds then there is a very
sparse vocal breakdown that sounds
almost like a call to prayer
and then after this section this track
is just
five straight minutes of the most
hellish
beauty i have heard in 2020 transmission
to mercury provides a very much needed
jazzy switch up in the track list i
think the
vocal work on this song is really
interesting and adds a lot of flavor
extreme
abrasive and freaky flavor the title
track of the record mostly gets by
with its very visceral grooves head
banging riffs
and guitar chords that are just
erratically
vibrating in tone it sounds like we have
like a lot of whammy bar usage maybe
on this song the chords are just
i can't quite describe them but the
guitar is
like nuts then we have a second half to
this track that to me is just
indescribably strange we have some
sci-fi
inspired synths more mayhem driven
guitars and drums
and these cultish coral sections that
are so
grand and theatrical they are
awe-inspiring
there is a similar brand of chaos
created on the greater good with more
vocals
more guitars more drums but with a
pretty interesting lyrical angle a
dystopian future where the
false choices given to us under
capitalism give way to
some kind of feudalistic consumerist
slave state where you buy do and believe
what you're told which conceptually is
nothing brand new for the band if you
take their older works into context
they're pretty comfortable with the idea
of portraying a grim
future there is a very familiar
instrumental build and aesthetic to this
track given how far we are into the
record at this point but still the
climax
is incredible plus this song does
feature some of the most
entertaining and ambitious bass
embellishments on the entire lp
moments that feel like free improv
moments that sound like a lot of tapping
is going on
now the two finishing tracks on this lpu
while not bad or not nearly as
gratifying or robust as many other
songs on the record we have experiment
which is some
kind of short standard very grim tech
death
there's not a lot special about this
number outside of maybe how smothering
and crushing the ending is
then happy home the closer of the record
i would say this is really the only
song on the lp that feels it's just
demented
for being demented's sake i suppose
it sounds like every weird and freaky
idea the band maybe had in mind for a
moment somewhere on this lp
all coming together into the ugliest
extreme metal tossed
salad ever now granted there are some
coherent melodies that translate out of
this
one and i suppose the somewhat kooky
vibe of the song does fit with
the mood of the rest of the record in a
way it's more theatrical and
and sort of campy elements i suppose
so i can't say it's a total waste even
if it doesn't make for the grandest
ending but that's maybe my biggest issue
with the lp at the end of the day there
is a lull in the first leg and then it
really fails to stick the landing but
everything else about the record
is stupendous excellent production
performances
writing really inventive super creative
and
incredibly original in some respects one
of the most unique
powerful and colorful listens i've had
with a metal record
this year feeling a decent two strong
